_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Stephenville Wastewater Treatment Plant (WWTP) has adopted this Risk Management Program to

implement 40 CFR 68, the federal requirements regulating risk management of an Extremely Hazardous

Substance (EHS). This Program will help prevent the occurrence of or minimize the consequences of,

catastrophic releases by stating our policies and procedures for the management of process hazards in startup,

operation, inspection, maintenance, and the other matters addressed in the federal standard.

This Executive Summary includes information required under 40 Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) 68.155.

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

The Stephenville WWTP implements a scheduled preventive maintenance program, including inspection

and testing, to minimize the potential for accidental releases. Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) have

been reviewed and revised to enable the employees to perform their work safely and efficiently.

The Stephenville WWTP staff are trained only to manage incidental releases related to maintenance and

operation activities and the facility is considered a non-responding facility per 40 CFR 68.90. Emergency

response to accidental releases is coordinated with the local fire department and local emergency planning

committee.

Stationary Sources and Regulated Substances

The Stephenville WWTP utilizes chlorine (regulated substance) as a biocide in the treatment of wastewater.

General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

A Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) as well as written process safety information has been developed to enable

personnel to identify and understand the hazards posed by processes involving highly hazardous chemicals

(HHC). Process safety information includes chlorine information, technology of the process information, and

equipment information.

The PHA completed for this Risk Management Plan (RMP)/Process Safety Management Plan (PSMP)

documents the process

and the findings to minimize or eliminate hazards, to mitigate the consequences of

hazards of any releases or other unplanned events, and to reduce the likelihood of exposure to chlorine.

Written procedures and information have been developed, implemented, and maintained for the hazardous

process, including steps for each operating phase, operating limits, safety and health considerations, and

safety systems and their functions. All employees involved in working with and around the chlorine system

are trained in process and safety procedures.

The mechanical integrity of chlorine process equipment is documented and maintained through

maintenance, inspection, and testing programs. In addition, a Management of Change program has been

established to ensure proper review of a proposed change to the chlorine system.

A pre-startup safety review is performed on new or modified processes to ensure that equipment and

construction meet design specifications, procedures and training have been implemented, and hazard

analysis recommendations are resolved prior to start-up.
